texts.shortText:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs, although some are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This species has a relatively elongate body for a sparid (body depth = head length) and a slightly protruding lower jaw with 4 large anterior canine teeth. The body is silvery-red, the red extending onto to pectoral and tail fins. The lateral line is conspicuous and the sides bear about 7 horizontal bands of blue spots alternating with silvery bands. The eyes are red.
Up to 80 cm total length and a mass of up to 5 kg, but most fish seen in shallower water much smaller than this.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Table Bay to KwaZulu-Natal.

Adults common on deeper reefs of 50-200 m, where form the basis of a significant fishery. Juveniles on shallower reefs from 10-40 m. A schooling species and has been recorded migrating over distances of at least 300 km.
Juveniles feed on small crustaceans and worms, while adults feed mostly on squid and small schooling fish, such as anchovy and pilchard.
Do not change sex. Females reach sexual maturity as a length of about 25-27 cm and males at 26-28 cm. Spawn throughout their range in December to April. Eggs develop in the plankton.

Colour pattern similar to that of Panga Pterogymnus laniarius, which is also pink and has horizontal bands of blue spots. However, Panga have a deeper body, flaring canine teeth and a blue line across the cheek.
